clinical_study.brief_title: Protein in Feeding Strategies to Accelerate Muscle Recovery From ACL Reconstruction
clinical_study.official_title: The Role of Beef in Optimal Protein and Feeding Strategies to Accelerate Muscle Mass and Functional Recovery From Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) Repair

collaborator.agency: United States Army Research Institute of Environmental Medicine

primary_outcome.measure: Skeletal muscle protein fractional synthetic rates
primary_outcome.time_frame: Following 16 weeks of physical rehabilitation post surgery for subjects in both diet intervention groups.
primary_outcome.description: Using stable isotope techniques skeletal muscle protein fractional synthetic rates will be determined

clinical_study.condition: Rehabilitative Nutrition for Muscle Recovery From ACL Reconstruction

arm_group.description: Diet Intervention - Adequate Protein (1.0 g/kg/d) - Carbohydrate Post Therapy [AP-CPT]
Diet Intervention - Optimal Protein (2.0 g/kg/d) - Protein Post Therapy [OP-PPT]

intervention.description: Adequate Protein_Carbohydrate Post Therapy (AP-CPT) where protein intake will be 1 g/kg/d for the duration of the study .
Optimal Protein_Protein Post Therapy (OP-PPT) with protein intake set at 2.0 g/kg/day for the duration of the study

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 to 35 years of age
- identified as appropriate for study recruitment by their respective orthopedic surgeon
- undergoing their first anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) repair
- undergo ACL reconstruction under general anesthesia
- body mass indexes (BMIs) within normal to overweight ranges
Exclusion Criteria:
- reporting metabolic or cardiovascular abnormalities, food allergies, gastrointestinal disorders (i.e. lactose intolerance)
- use of nutritional/herbal/sports supplements including anabolic steroids, and tobacco products will be excluded from the study
- BMIs above 29.9
